Moral [[anti-realism]] would hold that morality is derived from: any one of the [[norm (sociology)|norms]] prevalent in society ([[cultural relativism]]), the edicts of a god ([[divine command theory]]), merely the speakers' sentiments ([[emotivism]]), an implied imperative ([[universal prescriptivism]]), or an unsupported belief that there are objective moral facts ([[moral nihilism]]). Like the cultural relativist, the [[Moral relativism| moral relativist]] holds that there is no correct definition of right behavior, and that morality can only be judged with respect to particular situations within the standards of particular belief systems and socio-historical contexts. A key issue is the meaning of the terms "moral" or "immoral". Moral [[anti-realism]] would hold that morality is derived from: any one of the [[norm (sociology)|norms]] prevalent in society ([[cultural relativism]]), the edicts of a god ([[divine command theory]]), merely the speakers' sentiments ([[emotivism]]), an implied imperative ([[universal prescriptivism]]), or an unsupported belief that there are objective moral facts ([[moral nihilism]]). Like the cultural relativist, the [[Moral relativism| moral relativist]] holds that there is no correct definition of right behavior, and that morality can only be judged with respect to particular situations within the standards of particular belief systems and socio-historical contexts. This position often cites empirical evidence from anthropology of sharply contrasting views of "good" as supporting its claims.<ref>[http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-relativism/ Moral Relativism (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Poles apart are the views of [[Moral realism]], which hold that there are true moral statements that report objective moral facts. This may be the philosphical view propounded by supporters of the [[science of morality]]. For example, while [[Moral universalism|Moral universalists]] might concede that forces of social [[conformity (psychology)|conformity]] significantly shape individuals' "moral" decisions, they deny that those cultural [[norm (sociology)|norms]] and [[convention (norm)|customs]] define morally right behavior.

A disambiguation in the usage of the word 'morality' can be made however. In [[teleological ethics]] the word 'moral' is used as a [[synonym]] for ethical. In [[deontological ethics]] the word 'moral' is used in a more narrow sense: that act of which one can at the same time will that it becomes a [[universal]] [[law]]<ref>Kritik der Reinen Vernunft, Immanuel Kant</ref>. A remarkable consequence of this is that teleological ethics is immoral from a deontological viewpoint.

In [[deontological ethics]] the word 'moral' is used in a more narrow sense: that act of which one can at the same time will that it becomes a [[universal]] [[law]]<ref>Kritik der Reinen Vernunft, Immanuel Kant</ref>. A remarkable consequence of this is that teleological ethics is immoral from a deontological viewpoint.
